description:
This garage spaced, wooded ceiling is a refreshing addition to the Visitacion Valley neighborhood. 

Limited parking spots in front as well as limited seating, with some outdoor chairs therefore not ideal for a day of computer work. There is usually only one barista so the line naturally builds during the morning commute. 

However, great for a quick pick me up to order an affogato (ice cream + espresso) after lunch or dinner to fight the itis. Their almond mocha is robust with just a hint of chocolate sweetness. They also serve almond milk as an alternative to regular milk, but no soy.

Overall solid coffee spot surrounded by tons of restaurants.
author: Diana H.

description:
Lady with the septum ring , badly chopped bangs and medium blonde hair kept looking me up and down without even greeting me and my guest. No greeting or anything. Just a blank stare . (Hate your job much? )
We had ordered 2 cappucinos , 1 mocha and 1 chai latte . I asked if they had any soy milk or other dairy products in which she snarkily replied , "we only have almond milk." (That was literally the only thing she said during this entire interaction) .
After taking my order she had flipped over the ipad for a tip and finished transaction.. 
After my order was set she was gossiping with the young POC barista with a septum ring as well..cmon , there's a time and place for everything but that's not appropriate . 
A younger man then walked into the coffee shop and the lady with terrible service immediately walks over and starts flirting with this guy while the barista is obviously struggling to keep up orders. 
It took us around 15minutes for our order to be complete while the barista was hopping around orders and completing peoples orders after us.
The entire time the younger lady has this face like she just smelled sh!!t when interacting with customers .
The cappucino was grainy and not very strong.
The chai absolutely DID NOT have almond milk too .
This place is garbage .
There's a large amount of rumors that the owner is a pedofile anyway, i'll be avoiding this place .
author: Maddy F.

description:
The stars are literally just because this is the most charming building I've ever been in. It's so cute I kind of want to live here.

Alas,the dirty chai sucked.
author: Laura S.

description:
Modern coffee shops are some of the most aesthetically pleasing spots on the planet. And this one is no exception. This place is just cool. I felt cooler just walking into the place. The shop itself is quite small with limited seating, so I wouldn't consider this a good place to hunker down and set up shop to study for an extended length of time. But it is a pleasant place to sit and talk with a friend. They also have some outdoor seating in a beautiful urban garden. 

I had a latte and a slice of cinnamon/sugar toast which came out to a pretty steep total of $9. The toast was meh but the latte was warm and comforting. Parking is kind of rough. I circled a couple of times in the neighbor residential area but couldn't find anything. I ended of parking around the corner and paying the expensive SF meters.
author: Kim W.

description:
Such a cool space. You'd never even know it was here unless... you knew it was here. Grab a cup of Joe and have a seat. Stay a while and enjoy the gentle hum of conversation and coffee grinding.

You'd never even know the freeway was right next door.
author: Kevin J.

description:
File this place under: hit or miss. The best thing going for it is not posh toast, but rather the semi-shaded outside seating.

At this Four Barrel, the espresso drinks may be exceedingly hot and bitter (re-calibrate machine? check the grind? don't scald milk? all of the above?), or they may be fairly balanced & of decent temp., so that the sweetness of the milk comes through (& sometimes covers up the taste of an inferior pull). It really is a crap-shoot here, tbh.

Given the ball ache it is to find parking 'round these parts & that about 50% of the time the drinks aren't too palatable, it may be that this Portola outpost won't be visited much in future. Those of us keen on supporting local biz would do well to see what the Avenue might bring when it's again up and running. Better yet, let's push for a coffee joint worth its salt in what will surely be a mixed-use space housed in the former theatre. 

Capp: 4.50
Latte: 5.00
Go elsewhere: priceless
author: Bea B.

description:
WARNING --- NO RESTROOM. 
    A coffee place of that size with no restroom is ridiculous!
    That why I finally decided to drop a STAR ... especially that size ...
    and especially if it was owned by the Four Barrel Coffee group ...
    with the money they make and NO BATHROOM

A quaint modern space hidden in a dead end.
Nice interior ... but not design to chill out friendly.
      seem like the going trend ... come for the coffee ...
      not design for you to stay like Ritual on Valencia ...
      everytime they remodeled less place to sit or uncomfortable
       modernistic look (Big F deal) if you have no place to chill !!!
author: S.K. Y.

description:
So my friend lives down the street and I've come up from San Jose to visit from time to time. After brunch we walked back and stumbled on this location. Heavy breathing ensued as I LOVE coffee especially cute coffee shops. 

I told my friends to sound the alarm as I was going in and they could go on without me. They all agreed to stay with me and scoped out the cute outdoor area. There's even a free community  library; love It! 

It was a one man band and he was pleasant dude. It wasn't that busy when we went in (Sunday  around 12:30) so I was able to get my drink quickly. I ordered a Mocha, my goto drink. It was delicious. Just right amount of bitter to sweet.

I will be back for sure, it's a hidden gem. If you're just walking by!
author: Evangelina B.

description:
This location is not as big as their other ones but it's also never packed - a good trade-off. The smaller space meant a more limited menu but you will find all the main caffeine drinks. Prices are high for the neighborhood but it is nice to have something upscale amongst noodle houses and eateries in the area.

Not far from Alemany Blvd or Hwy 101, though finding it is tough since it's in a side alley off San Bruno Ave. Parking in the area is limited most of the. There are only half dozen metered spots outside and are always taken!
author: Peter L.

description: This place is hidden at the alley. Small, cozy, and hipster coffee shop! I came here on Saturday around lunch time. Music is not too loud and not many people were here. It is perfect place to talk and have a conversation with your friend.
author: Davis Y.

description: I thought the coffee was average.  Maybe just wasn't to my taste and I am an addicted coffee drinker.  Nice staff and customer service
author: FG L.

description: The 1 Star is for the 20% of coffees I get from this place that are good.  80% of the time it's horrible.  The past 4 times have been the worst.  I just went today and even asked the barista to remake it cause it was that bad.  The second one was also bad but in a slightly different way - like if you're going to be bad At least be consistent. I actually used to get decent coffees from this location but the quality has just plummeted lately if you're going to charge $5.75 for a mocha it should be better than what I can get from my Nespresso machine.  Specifically the issues are 1) can't taste coffee at all - tastes like milk only cause they aren't pulling the espresso correctly and 2) even the milk texture and foam is bad -completely wrong consistency.
author: Olivia T.

description:
Great coffee and fun converted garage space.

Sucky parking situation.  No bathroom so don't expect to drink too much.
author: S F.

description:
Nice little spot in Portola! The coffee shop is rather small, and not many people know that there is a Four Barrel at this location. The coffee is always amazing, and I always come here to buy different varieties of whole beans. There is never more than 4 people here whenever I stop by, which is great because I can always find a spot to sit at one of the tables! 

They also sell toast at this location - cinnamon/sugar, almond butter/honey, etc. 

My only complaint is that every time I'm here there are a lot of flies inside the shop...
author: Jeanette S.

description:
I have always been a fan of good coffee. I am a fan of Four Barrel but I'm from Oakland so Blue Bottle Coffee is so convenient to me that I really don't need to go across the bridge and fight through traffic just to get to the Four Barrel in the mission.
But one day while waiting for brunch at Breakfast at Tiffany's, my friend told me there's a Four Barrel hidden down the street. I could not believe that the Portola district has its own hidden gem of Four Barrel. Parking can be difficult, the coffee shop can be hard to find, but once you find it, it's definitely Sunshine! 
I had to refuel my Coffee shelf at home anyway, so I grabbed a bag of 
COLOMBIA LUCAS MELO and was going to order just a cup of pour over coffee when the lady told me a bag of coffee comes with a free cup of coffee so it worked out.
Beans are pricey - $22 for 12 ounces but hey, you get what you pay for. Just grinded my beans and made my first pour over of this coffee this morning and it has definitely made a rainy day a little bit brighter. 
This cafe - limited seating, maybe quick conversation, get a coffee, take a walk around the block, super cute though!
author: Miffy Y.

description: Quaint shop with really good, not cheap, coffee. Parking is a challenge because of the location but not impossible. They have an open floor plan and a lovely garden with limited outdoor seating which is enjoyable on a beautiful SF day.
author: Jay F.

description:
Thought I would give this neighborhood Four Barrel another try since there aren't too many great coffee shops in this area. I've been here a few times and I always get the same thing: iced latte with almond milk. Every time I order it, the taste is always inconsistent, and the last time believe it or not there was a hair in my coffee :'( 

Today I came back and ordered the same thing, and unfortunately my latte tasted really off and I couldn't figure out what it was. After about 20 mins or so, everything started separating and I noticed half of the cup was diluted with regular coffee or something. I know what a latte is suppose to look and taste like so I didn't get why it had two different colors, that is not suppose to happen.

This location needs to be consistent with their drinks and I don't think other locations in the city do this but the employees should be making their lattes correctly and not mix it with Americanos or whatever. 

Not sure if I will come back and spend $5 for coffee here anymore.
author: Elisa S.

description: Mmmm coffee and Hot Chocolate!  What a great space to enjoy coffee from the street to the standing bar facing the roasting machines in the back.  The drip coffee bar was a nice to have option when ordering your daily dose of caffeine if you're willing to wait some time.
author: Anthony E.

description: Pretty neat space, tight parking, and the guy working there was really short and distant. Not sure why I'd pay so much for a slice of toast and butter so we both got a hot beverage to enjoy during our drive. It was subpar for the amount we paid for and the guy's lack of service makes me think how this place is so good. Would not recommend for those visiting.
author: Jackie R.

description: So many coffee shops that I have been to its worth a try to check out another one. And that's why I have chosen this one next. The place is really cool. Grabbed myself a cup of Joe and had a seat. Stayed for little while until I was done with my coffee. The experience was truly nice. Worth recommending to others.
author: Natasha R.

description:
Cute location tucked away in Portola. 

My boyfriend and I each had lattes and ordered a slice of the toast with butter and cinnamon sugar. I wouldn't splurge on Four Barrel on the regular, but I liked the vibe at this location.

The cafe had a good amount of seating both inside and outside. There was plenty of parking on San Bruno Ave. and the surrounding streets, and added bonuses were the community garden and little free library across the street.

Go down the street and grab an egg custard or pineapple bun at Red House Bakery if you don't feel like paying $4 for a slice of toast!
author: Camille B.

description: This place is a little hard to find, but i'm glad we did.  The coffee was amazing!  There weren't many places to sit here and it was drizzling so we didn't want to sit on the random stools on the sidewalk, but it was still worth the stop.  Unfortunately there were a TON of flies swarming around inside the shop, so that was a little off putting, but we found a spot away from them and enjoyed their amazing coffee.
author: Geena G.

description:
Great hole-in-the-wall coffee spot. Good coffee + friendly service = good experience. 
(Good luck finding a parking spot anywhere near)
author: JonJon W.

description:
Cute coffee shop near my work WHOOO! The vibe and the interior is very hipster, but I'm a fan of this place. This place is a cool place to just chat with friends as well. So far I have just tried the cappuccino. It is $4, no tax, the price is okay to me I guess. The cup is 8 oz, on the smaller size, but the cup decoration is so cute I didn't want to throw the cup away. 

Cappuccino: Great foam art and taste! I didn't add any sugar or milk to it at all cause I don't think it's necessary. The price is worth it cause of the premium quality! Very exquisite. 

Service: Friendly and great energy! There's only one guy working when I went and he definitely knew what he was doing. I'll definitely be back!
author: Vanessa L.

description: Sigh. I hoped to like my mocha way more seeing that I had spent $5.75 on it. It didn't taste very good (almost like a bad hot chocolate) and left a gross aftertaste in my mouth. The reason that I still gave it 3 stars was because the awesome atmosphere and service made up for it. They also have a cute neighborhood cat and dog that come by the store and greet customers.
author: Jana Z.

description:
Imagine yourself lost and with no sense of time. 

You somehow ended up in the neighborhood of Portola. It seems familiar yet unfamiliar at the same time. There are a couple Asian ladies shouting out loud, a few men jay walking and some kids trying to cause a scene. You overcome the distractions and end up in a corner with a somewhat open garage place. You're not sure what it is, but the garden next to it seems like a safe enough place. You look around for clues as to what this place is. Alas, there's a sign that that says Four Barrel Coffee. The name sounds familiar, yet unfamiliar as to why it would be located here of all places. 

The decor inside starts to bring you to peace. The lovely wooden scheme and some merchandise for sale/looks. The menu is simple for everyone. One Mocha to bring me back to reality. One toast with butter and honey to reconfirm this existence. The mocha was balanced excellently. The toast was simple and did its job. 

This place was relaxing. I was even able to play with a dog that some customer decided to bring along. The table was spacious enough for light reading and the natural lighting was a great bonus. For those bookless creatures out there, you can grab a book from their Little Garden. A friendly word of advice is to sanitize your hands before and after the book.

Sometimes, getting lost is better than having a direction.
author: Fiona L.

description: Hip place. Hipstery vibes. Workers were nice and friendly. Got a latte and a free black coffee that came with the beans we purchased. The latte was warm and creamy, perfectly made topped with your usual latte art.
author: Kimberly L.

description: With a cute facade in my neighborhood, I wanted to check this place out. I was about to get a mocha but realized it was $5.75 and was not down to pay that much, so I opted for an iced chai latte. I didnt want much ice because it'd water down my drink, and when I told the barista, they said no problem - they just wouldn't fill the extra space with more latte. Makes sense for sure UNTIL I saw how much I actually got for my $4.50 latte. It was literally HALF the cup (if I'm being generous). It would've been fine if the drink was tasty, but it was so flavorless that if I closed my eyes, I'd think I was drinking water. I wanted to like this place but I really cant. There is so much hype around this place that it's underwhelming.
author: Sophie D.

description:
The cutest little hidden gem in San Francisco. I live in the area and I can't believe I never discovered this place until recently. This small coffee shop is hidden in a garage on a dead end street. Right outside the shop you will see an adorable little garden on the side of a freeway wall. There's a cute little bridge and a bookshelf labeled 'free library'. How adorable right? 

As for the coffee, everything is pretty simple and decently priced. The coffee menu is mounted on the wall but on a sunny day can be a little hidden. I've tried the vanilla latte and the regular iced coffee, both are pretty good. Give this place a visit if you are in the city, you won't regret it!
author: Lushi Z.

description: I would recommend the latte. It's honestly the best I've ever had. Plenty of street parking available. There's no wifi (that's what the barista told us) and there's limited seating.
author: Kimberly G.

description:
We only stopped in for a quick bite and pick-me-up before our flight home, and we left blown away by this place! Our cinnamon sugar toast was delicious ($4), and the laidback, natural light ambiance was unbeatable. I was so thrilled that I'd stumbled upon a "catfe" (alas, my attempts at making a feline friend were foiled) and even got to take a cheeky picture outside in the gorgeous garden. 

We walked, but parking looked like it could be a pain in this cul-de-sac. But we'll definitely be coming back when we're back in town!
author: Kimi R.

description:
Good coffee in this neighborhood is hard to find so this place is a unicorn.

Coffee is good 
The ability to come hang out and work or chill not so much because comfortable seating is nonexistent. No comfort. Just wood seat benches . Lots of sun outside but it's like a cave inside and tiny.

Enjoy the Coffeee!!!!
author: Gigi A.

description: Sooo hipster. I've tried the latte, machiatto, and chai latte so far. They're all solid drinks and not too sweet. Slightly pricey but I like the ambiance of sitting outside with my coffee by the tree and chatting with friends. They have lots of pretty flowers out there.
author: Tes Y.

description:
Portola doesn't strike me as a hipster haven, but sure enough, it looks like Four Barrel opened a third shop in this working class neighborhood. I came upon it quite by accident as I was heading back to my car after a heaping bowl of menudo at Cinco de Mayo Taqueria. It's not competing with the commercial chaos on sidewalk-congested San Bruno Avenue, at least not directly. You actually walk into a cul-de-sac of sorts, the dead end of Burrows Street (...or more accurately, the beginning) right off San Bruno. You come upon a wide colorful mural with plenty of plastic stools strewn about (photo: http://bit.ly/1A7jfdz) and what looks to be the makings of a wildflower garden. Turn your head to the left and you see Four Barrel Coffee in all its urban-cool glory.

It's not so much a cafe as it is a spruced-up, compact warehouse space (photo: http://bit.ly/13x65JE). Look up and you see recycled redwood pipes in a decorative pattern on the ceiling (photo: http://bit.ly/1Ehk33q). The menu is small, just ten coffee variations and some baked goods that come from a Dogpatch bakery called fittingly Neighbor. I had a silken smooth $4.50 Latte which I placed properly on one of the little peninsulas jutting out from the adjacent wall (photo: http://bit.ly/1HEKbla). I could well imagine local musicians jamming and neighborhood mixers that bring humanity together in peaceful harmony. Or maybe that was Woodstock. I don't remember because I was on an acid trip. Anyway, you should come here because something so unexpectedly bucolic shouldn't be ignored. Besides, it's Four Barrel.

COFFEE - 4 stars...Four Barrel in a surprising setting
AMBIANCE - 5 stars...urban underbelly renewal done in a model way that other challenged areas should emulate
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...a bit on the hipsterish side
TOTAL - 4 stars...a solid 4 for an outsider like me but closer to a 5 if you live in Portola
author: Ed U.

description:
Located in the corner of a dead end alley, four barrel is consistent with its beautiful minimalist design and decor. 

Selection is limited since they probably don't have as much stocked as the main location on Valencia. I wanted a vanilla latte, but that wasn't available so they suggested getting a mocha. He was a skilled pourer, so extra points for that!

There's only a few tables and seats inside and a cool-looking bench on the outside. 

Metered parking is available right outside, but if you walk a couple blocks down you could get lucky with residential street parking.
author: Marjo M.

description: I can't say much about their coffee but their hot chocolate is the WORST hot chocolate I've ever tasted in my life. Seriously, the dollar hot chocolates at the coffee machines taste better. And a quarter of the price. Seriously, a $4 hot chocolate?! Save your money for philz. I get this city ain't cheap to live in but you got to stop selling those shit hot chocolates that you even call hot chocolate. Is their even chocolate in them? Please stop selling them or make them cheaper or tastier.
author: Samuel B.

description: I love that this place exists so close to my house! I'm hoping that San Bruno Ave will continue to have places like 4barrel for this up and coming neighborhood. I love that they offer almond milk chai and their treats are delish. It's even a great spot to pick up a gift...their mugs are awesome.
author: Mimi C.

description: Love this coffee shop. Four Barrel Coffee is great and this me design of this place is beautiful.  Great find in Portola district.
author: Eric G.

description:
Yay a decent coffee shop not too far from home! Perfect for those days I just don't feel like driving for a good cup of coffee.

Four Barrel is a little hidden hipster haven tucked in the corner of a small alley way on San Bruno Ave.

They serve good quality coffee. They're menu is simple and concise. They offer drip coffee, espresso, lattes, cappuccinos, machiattos, americanos, mochas, and affogatos ($6). To my knowledge, they only offer one size. Price from $3-$5. Extra $0.50 for almond milk. When I was there, they didn't have flavored syrup such as vanilla or hazelnut. And they only have whole milk.

I ordered a latte extra foamy. The barista did a cute latte art leaf. The latte could have been foamier, but I was still very happy with it. Maybe I should try asking for a wet capp next time.

Their cups, sleeves, and lids are all 100% compostable (no surprise for a hipster shop). The lid is a bit flimsy in my opinion, but it did it's job.

The shop itself is very small and cute with very limited seating. They could use a few more tables and chairs outside. But they do have a nice wall mural and I hear sometimes they have a live band playing outside.

They do have baked goods which I want to try next time.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
I love this. Not only is it soooo close to me. but they are open early.
you can drive up, park and go.
Strong coffee. The best thing is the toast. OH my the TOAST.
They give you options of spread like sea salt, sugar, honey, fresh jams. LOVE.
author: francis c.

description: So I came back since my first but quick experience was pretty good. Service still pretty good. Ordered the toast which is pretty tasty. Ice mocha - strong. Still pricy. So I brought my iPad to hopefully to get some work done. They have minimum seating, some bar seating and one large table that seats four people with stool seats. No bathroom and no wi-fi. Definitely, a quick fast stop coffee joint. I would only come back if I need coffee on the go.
author: Sarah C.

description: Make no mistake, this is where the good coffee is. It holds up even three hours old in my cup. And live for the almond butter and jam toast --pricey, but worth it!
author: Teresa D.

description: Their cinnamon, butter toast is poppin!! The decor is very hipster and the vibes are even more hipster. Staff is super sweet and really friendly; they have a store cat named Boots and she is 1/2 the reason I want to come back. She loves to be petted and brings everyone together. Parking is a little limited, but it's not necessarily somewhere you stay for a while, so spots are opened quite frequently. The store has limited seating but great outdoor space. I'd come back again! :)
author: Fern S.

description:
The location was beautiful and the coffee was the same. 

We went by on Saturday and they were pretty busy, but the service and wait was great. 

Scooped up a miir cup while we were there as well and they put my drink in there on the fly! 

Stop by and get down good coffee.
author: Will M.

description:
Delicious.

Four Barrel coffees have always been one of my favorites - rich, flavorful, never too acidic and absolutely never burnt tasting.  I have even tried their coffee at the Rose Establishment in SLC, Delfina, B Patisserie and several restaurants/cafes in SF and it's been consistently good.

During a break in my schedule I decided to pick up a cappuccino and a slab of the $4 toast.  The cappuccino, made with whole milk, was creamy and frothy and hot, but at just the right temperature to drink immediately.  Perfection.

Yep, I was one of those that made fun of the $4 toast.  $4 for a slice of bread and some spreads? $4 for for something I could make myself at home?  Well, that slice of toast is as thick as two regular slices of bread.  It's hearty, flavorful and very fresh.  This is not something pumped out of an assembly line or sitting on a store shelf for days.  That bread is really good.  The bread was toasted and topped with generous portions of creamy butter, cinnamon and sugar.  Yum.  

So $4 for a small cappuccino and $4 for toast.  Was it worth it?  Initially I thought that these items were ridiculously overpriced but now I have to say that I'm completely full and completely satisfied.  A few hours after consumption and I'm still not hungry.  It's all about quality at Four Barrel, not quantity.

The menu is limited and that's a good thing.  This is not a Starbucks so there is no made up names for cup sizes, no blended iced drinks and syrups, chocolate drizzles, whipped cream or other such nonsense that  turn a cup of coffee into dessert.   Options for milk are whole milk or almond milk.  There's sugar and syrup for sweeteners.  This is what cafes used to be like before the introduction of the mega-chain coffee outlets, where the primary focus is on the coffee itself.

Parking can bet hit or miss in this area.  On some afternoons parking is nonexistent.  On this morning, parking was plentiful.  As others have mentioned there is seating but not many options for tables.
author: Melissa L.

description:
The decor is nice, the staff is nice.
The chairs/stools are wildly uncomfortable.
The coffee tastes unpleasant.
I tried this place twice and I was bummed because I live so close!
No dice.
author: Rehan K.

description:
Four Barrel Coffee, welcome to the Portola District.

Good coffee with latte art and friendly staff member on duty. I came in for the first time today and liked it. I was very thirsty upon getting off the 8x, so I walked over here and ordered a latte. There are seats available inside and outside so that is a good thing. Converting this unit into a coffee shop is a very good use of the space.

I lived in San Francisco for 26 years now and I am very grateful to see Four Barrel Coffee here.

They are conveniently located right behind a Subway Sandwich shop on the corner of San Bruno Ave & Burrows St. For anyone of you looking for the place to taste good coffee, you found the right spot.

There are a few spots to park your car right in front!

Edit for 9/2/2016:
The sourdough toast is delicious and crunchy when toasted. This pastry item also pairs well with a fresh brewed cup of coffee.
author: Bennett W.

description:
I've been back a few times but I suppose my original review needs an update.

I love their lattes but I really wonder who are the people who spend $5 for a latte and $4 for toast. Cray cray. For those prices, the employees should be able to keep the dead end street clean of garbage. I realize it's a wind tunnel in the Portola but I don't think it is too much to ask for the employees to sweep the short street 1x/hour so one can enjoy the uber expensive coffee in a clean setting.

I suspect Jeremy would still be making a very nice living if he charged 1 buck less.
author: Laura M.

description: No wifi, but lots of seating and a great place to hotspot and work! No outlets! Great service and incredibly nice baristas.
author: Aashima G.

description:
Review strictly on service. Been here a few times and I just can't understand why it's so hard for the staff to be friendly here. I never get a hello when I walk in, no smiles or greeting, and no thank you or have a nice day to end the transaction. The conversation today literally ended with him telling me the price. And mind you... I usually tip pretty damn well. ($2 or $1 per coffee I order). I handed his tip today because he already took his tip jar away and he takes the money and says "oo"  and. continues talking to his coworker. Um.. You meant to say "thank you" right? ... Jerk -__-

Anyways, the coffee is good. I always grab one for my friend everytime I go to her house which is pretty close by. :)
author: Jennifer T.

description: Hole in the wall and a pleasant niche coffeeshop with a creative interior now serving a diversity of toast and toppings.
author: Michael K.

description: The place is a cozy spot with amazing toast and coffee. The bread ON POINT. Very friendly and accommodating baristas but Taking off stars due to the lack of disclaimers for their nut milks. Asked for an ALMOND milk latte, had a sip and knew immediately something was off and when I asked if other nuts were used, they said it was cashew, which I am VERY ALLERGIC to. It is not friendly to those with dairy/nut restrictions. PLEASEEE please please inform your customers what goes into your nut milks.
author: Christina M.

description: A cute little outpost in Portala with none of the crowds but all of the good coffee and aesthetics you expect from a Four Barrel. Just a really lovely place to stop for coffee with lots of outdoor seating and a mural, tucked away on a dead-end street in the middle of the Portola main drag.
author: Jean K.

description: i am not a huge fan of FBC but I like the location and the layout. Moreover, the young lady working there was super nice and welcoming. They sell food and drink therefore should offer bathroom access.. I will be back
author: maven r.

description: Finally a cute coffee shop near my house. #gentrification haha. My boyfriend and I come here every Sunday. (New tradition) We walk the dogs over, one of us sits down on the nicely put together hill on the side with rocks to sit on all the way up and the other orders the coffee. Sometimes the coffee is better than other times and sometimes the service is better than other times. I've dealt with a snotty girl who apparently Was still hung over or a man who seemed to have some where else better to be but I have also been served by a girl very good at her job. This place always has customers, fairly busy. Mostly come here out of convenience and cuteness of location.
author: Carlie B.

description:
Horrible location...it took me over 10 minutes to find parking around noon. This location is cute and quaint in the back corner of a little parking lot. But don't let that deter you! Four Barrel offers great coffee. I ordered the mocha which is made with their Friendo Bendo Espresso beans. 

The website's description: "CITRUS FLAVORS SWAN DIVE INTO FRESH BERRY FULL FORWARD FOLD, WHICH JUMPS OR WALKS BACK INTO DOWN DOG, THEN ASCENDS INTO A TOFFEE SWEETNESS SUN SALUTATION. SWAN DIVE." 

Perfect for all you yogis! Haha jk. It's definitely different than other espressos for mocha, with more citrus and berry notes than nutty. I'll probably be back at the other locations hoping their parking isn't as bad...
author: Kim N.

description:
After my first cup ever, I already feel like a coffee snob. Is that bad?!

First of all, love the location. Props to whoever decided to set up shop here instead of just the Mission, SoMA or Downtown. The potential they saw by supporting this community is beyond words and takes a true visionary. 

After reading other reviews, I knew I had to get "the toast". And that's exactly how I ordered it. My options for the 2 toppings included: butter, almond butter, honey, jam and I think I'm forgetting another. I chose almond butter and honey. It was a 1/2 inch-3/4 inch toasted slice of rye with delicious flavor. Honestly, $4 for a piece of toast sounded ridiculous but I couldn't even finish half of it. It's a generous size and you will be well-fed for breakfast or even lunch.

And the pièce de résistance, the beverage. My iced latte was light, creamy and by far the best I've had. Forget the grande/venti stuff, I'd get a regular sized latte at Four Barrel any day.
author: Cindy T.

description: It 's not you, it's me. $4 for toast. $3.25  for a 12 oz coffee. Uncomfortable benches in a windswept alcove, the cloud of hip settles over the location's beautiful garden, while all of San Bruno Ave floats down river, as I emerge, angry at my self, $7.25 poorer joining the multitudes of folks who are just not cool enough to understand . I sip the coffee, it's good, but .. it's so small.
author: Brian P.

description:
This place is seriously a hidden gem, I only found it by stumbling upon while looking for parking in the area. It is now my favorite cafe in SF and has made me a coffee snob! 

I just moved to SF early this year and had never even heard of Four Barrel beforehand, now I'm literally there every Saturday morning since we have to endure shitty coffee everyday at work. (we deserve quality coffee in life on the weekends)

The latte and their pistachio croissant makes a perfect light breakfast combo. The prices are inexpensive and it's not over crowded. Awesome urban feel and deco. It's the best kept secret, soo sshh don't tell everyone and their coffee drinking mama.
author: Tone P.

description:
Adorable Toast.
I really expected to gush over coffee. I had heard so many great things about Four Barrel. I was excited to try it. Instead this review is really about adorable toast. 

My order for a cappuccino was taken by an enthusiastic young woman working the register. I needed a pastry to go with my coffee, and was pretty much down to a chocolate bear claw. But wait! "Have you considered our toast", she asked. Hmmm afternoon toast with my coffee. She can tell I'm not excited. With great care and detail, she fills me in on the toast. Apparently they source bread from someone whose name I was supposed to recognize. (Sorry bread person. I'm sure you're well known and super nice. I don't recall your name.) I was suddenly self conscious regarding my obvious ignorance of fine toast. Tartine bread I've heard of, but this was, well, toast. The grain was sourced in CA, totally organic, and milled by said bread person. "We top it with almond butter and a sprinkle of sea salt." Never have I seen someone so genuinely into toast. She was quite simply adorable.

So needless to say, I got the toast. It was a thick slab, with little sparkles of sea salt glistening in the afternoon sun. I took a photo of the toast. I texted co-workers about this toast. Later that evening, I told my girlfriend the story of what was now The Toast. I am now up way too early, writing Yelp! reviews for a coffee shop, but primarily focused on The Toast.

The Toast was pretty good. But all said and done, I should have taken a photo of the adorable woman that worked there. It was refreshing to meet someone obviously enjoying life,  particularly while at work. Thank you adorable toast woman.

P.S. Back to the coffee. My cappuccino was very good. Though I think as far as San Francisco choices go, I still prefer Blue Bottle for a cap. I'll have the give Four Barrel pour-over a shot if I make it back.
author: Dennis V.

description:
YEAH BUDDY..Four barrel has made its way to Portola/Visitaction Valley/Southeastern part of  SF that is neglected. Hello Trouble Coffee, there is a new kid in the neighborhood. 

VERY small location. Besides a small bar-ish counter,  there's no tables really. I estimate about 6 stools available.  It's the size of a garage. Beautiful woody ceiling decor. Unfortunately, due to size and lack of seating (as least for now I hope), this is more of a grab and go type of deal. 

Expect to just get quality coffee and off you go.
author: Danny Y.

description:
Four Barrel Coffee is my favorite place to get an expresso drink in the city. This location is a cute and artsy hole in the wall with indoor and outdoor seating. Hipster/vintage vibes and all that good stuff. 

I don't typically drink a Cup of Joe, so I can't say that I am a coffee enthusiast, but I am a latte enthusiast. I've tried lattes at multiple coffee shops in the bay area(Blue Bottle, Ritual, Philz, Trouble, and Reveille to name a few) but I haven't found anything that beats Four Barrel lattes thus far. The lattes are creamy and rich, but not overly bitter or milky- it is a perfect chemistry of both ingredients. The quality of the latte is always consistent and never has a burnt or sour taste that I occasionally taste at some coffee shops I have been to.

I have been a loyal customer of Four Barrel, first in the Valencia location and now this one here that is closer to my house, and I have noticed that the prices of the drinks have racked up drastically, maybe even more than I am willing to pay for. It is $5 for a latte + $0.50/$0.75 to substitute for almond milk, making a cup of latte almost $6, which is the price I usually paid for a pastry and latte.

Although Four Barrel is my favorite go-to coffee shop, I am not convinced that the tradeoff between smooth and rich coffee vs. $6 is worth dropping the money to buy on a daily basis, especially for a broke college student. However, Four Barrel is too good to cut out entirely out of my diet. I will definitely continue my reign of loyalty...in moderation!
author: Shirley L.

description:
I love that this Four Barrel is right in my hood! It's pretty uncommon to see nicer coffee shops around here. 

This Four Barrel is definitely very small and unassuming- it's located in a tiny alleyway off of San Bruno ave. It has that industrial, warehouse feel inside. It's not the type of coffee shop you'd want work or study at, but there are a few seats inside and stools/benches outside if you want to hang out while enjoying your coffee.

The barista was very knowledgable and gave really great descriptions of each coffee option on the menu.

I ordered a cappuccino and it was delicious! I'll give extra points because I'm a huge sucker for coffee art..what can I say? It makes a cute Instagram picture! :)

The one thing that bothered me was how many flies were inside. I know it's hard to control because the doors are open but I didn't like swatting flies out of my face while waiting for my coffee.
author: Melody Y.

description:
After hearing that Four Barrel was to my neighborhood,  I was so excited.   My Facebook post,  instagram posts,  and pins about Four Barrel over the years really hyped up the visit. It wasn't 5 stars (a bit dusty) but definitely a solid 4!!!

My first impression was that this location,  despite the increasingly heavy foot traffic, is so much more accessible.  On/off 101, and be sure to park one street up for free several hour parking.  I loved the ceiling made of wood blocks! 

The menu of drinks and pastry selection is the same as the other location although the ambiance is definitely quieter.   Amazing place to meet friends. Favorite drinks include the hot chocolate&the lattes--they do great latte art depending on the barista.

I like that at this location they source different cups and also have self serve water and easier to move stools.

Definitely am going to be a regular! :D
author: Jennifer Y.

description: It's great to have a coffee spot right in the neighborhood. I like the set-up they have, the outdoor sitting, the staff is always nice and attentive. So no complaints there. The only issue is the pricey coffee. $4 for an iced coffee (small) - not sure if they have large, but yeah. Coffee is not bad, but can definitely find better for cheaper.
author: J M.

description: This location gets one star. Unfriendly service AND the guy told me they don't do pour over at this location. As one of the top coffee shops in the city, they should keep the products consistent. I ended up getting an iced coffee that was watered down, not worth the hard earned $4.
author: E T.

description: Not to shabby...this place is a cool hidden gem in Portola I like it. It has a really cool SF industrial vibe to it. Service is great and drinks are pretty good. It is kind of pricey though, but it's a good spot to sit and sip and give yourself a break or catch up with a friend! I dig it!
author: Marie P.

description:
Gibraltar Review

The Pour:
Very good, beans are good they use Straus Family Creamery milk so it really is top notch

Service:
Baristas are all skilled at pulling the shot and the latte art, and very friendly and helpful

Ambiance:
Clean, relaxed and only moderately hipster, but tiny compared to the 4B location on Valencia

Conclusion:
Pretty much the same as the Valencia location - parking here is impossible, even harder than in the Mission

About Me / Review Criteria:
-I only check out / review "Third Wave" coffee
-Nobody gets more than 4 stars until I've gone several times
-Reviews can't be based on just a select group of baristas, they all have to be equally skilled, or at least must all have a minimum level of skill
-My star ratings are solely based on the drink, never on food, ambiance, or if the barista is emo or snobby (because that would bring down more than 50% of the shops), although I do mention those in the review
-I don't claim to be a trained coffee connoisseur but I know the difference between good and bad coffee
-My reviews are generally based on cappuccinos (or gibraltars), not espresso or drip coffee
author: Bernard F.

description:
Solid coffee!! Great service, decent price... What else can you ask for?? 

Good job focusing!! I'll be back for sure!!
author: JC C.

description: Best coffee, hands down. Parking is a challenge. Garage turned cafe near the garden plot makes it a peculiar stand out from the neighborhood... thank god!
author: Sergio M.

description:
*Review on Service Only*

Latte was above average and the temperature was almost perfect to drink immediately.

The service provided by the red-headed female order taker however, was well below average. 
I asked a simple question about ingredients in the ordered latte and her facial expression was that of "are you stupid?"
Seems like the epitome of an SF coffee snob hang-out. These are a dime a dozen in SF and needless to say I can find another w/ less rude service.
author: Max G.

description: It's so refreshing to have a secluded little hipster coffee shop in this area. Parking is difficult luckily I live close enough to walk. I ordered a latte and toast. Each cup of coffee is brewed fresh. I ordered the latte and it was perfect. You can even choose to substitute for almond milk. The design the barista makes in the foam also gives it a nice touch.  What I really enjoyed was the honey and almond butter toast. The barista suggested adding sea salt to the spread and I am glad I did. The sea salt was a nice balance between the almond butter and the honey. I can't remember exactly what type of bread they use here but it was thick piece of toast which was toasty but very soft on the inside. It is a bit on the pricier side but I don't mind. There are places to sit outside but it can be kinda dirty since there are a bunch of trees near by. Can't wait to try to come back!
author: Brigitte M.

description: This is one of our favorite coffee places however they have become v short handed lately. We went Sunday morning and there was only one guy working the entire shop so with the v long line, we waited for abt ten and left without ordering because we couldn't wait not to mention we had to illegally park since there is no parking close by. 5 stars for the coffee for sure, giving 3 stars here to alert the mgmt team to better staff the shop. Will come back for sure but hopefully w a shorter line.
author: Brian T.

description:
I stumbled upon 4 barrel during a visit to the Subway Restaurant  next door. Unfortunately there wasn't any parking near by but the barista offered to allow me to park for 10 minutes while I enjoyed my drip coffee. 

The 10 minutes allowed me to enjoy my coffee and grab a sandwich next door. 

I was blown away by the craft coffee and would love to return should I be in the area again. Hopefully next time I could stay for longer than 10 mins :)
author: Ryan T.

description: Very cool coffee shop tucked away in a cup de sac.    OUTSTANDING iced coffee.  Definitely 5 stars!
author: Todd B.

description:
The toast is amazingly good with some spreads! but everything is super pricey for its size. Not really the place for youngsters that don't have a lot of money to go. But it is a cool "hole-in-the-wall" and hipster place to come and check out. 

Seating is awkward. You have to sit on those plastic chairs in the designated area outside of the store. Parking is vey hard in the San Bruno area.
author: Annie D.

description: Best fair trade coffee on the planet.  I live in AZ, so I order beans.  However, when in the city I always always stop by & stock up.  Best almond milk lattes.  Wish you'd open a location in the desert.  Love Four Barrel!
author: Szervous Y.

description: This is very cool/hip coffee shop and iys in a hidden location which makes it even more appealing employess are very chill people and coffee is pretty good
author: Tony V.

description: I love this place! Every time I'm here the workers go above and beyond. Obviously, the coffee here is delicious, I'm glad four barrel opened up because there's no other place around this neighborhood to get good coffee.
author: Tracy V.

description: the young hip twenty-somethings that were working today had a somewhat "fresh out of my angsty phase" vibe. But yeah, this place attracts a very specific kind of affluence that is relatively rare in this neighbourhood. Bourgeois coffee at gentrified prices, enjoy.
author: Deez S.

description:
This coffee shop vibrants up the neighborhood. I went to high school near the San Bruno Ave. Before, we didn't have any cute hipster coffee shop...at all. 

I went in this place for the first time and ordered a mocha. Man, the mocha was strong, earthy and thick... great mocha. 

Let's talk about the environment. It is only a garage transformed coffee shop, but  the inside was so clean and spacious. So simple, they only have a counter with some coffee equipment in the back, the front of the  shop has a cart with all the coffee creamer, water, napkin, etc. The ceiling is the vocal point of store. I saw wood pieces assembled together and create these beautiful wave liked patterns. The phrase, less is more, can truly apply to this coffee shop. 

Well, of course, there is a trade off, there is no seating space at all inside the shop. There are only two small outdoor table outside the shop. I think it is good enough for now... in addition to that, there are some artsy wall benches along the wall from San Bruno ave all the way extend to Four Barrel. Again, artsy. they can also used for seating... I don't know if those benches were designed for the coffee shop or they just happened to be there. Overall, great coffee, friendly services, adds diversities to the neighborhood 5 STARS
author: Evan L.

description:
Where can you find the best coffee in the Portola district? Right here! Hidden behind the Subway and in the back of sorta an alley way... hide the best coffee place you can find in this area. So glad I came across Four Barrel because I normally drive 20 mins from my house to get coffee and this place is literally 2 min away from my house. Parking right outside makes it super convenient. 

Pourover coffee, ice coffee, macchiatos, they have it all! Smells so good as you walk in and even though there's not a lot of tables to sit at, there's plenty of stools and seating to sit outside! Lovin' their wood roof too!
author: Carmen C.

description:
A hipster cafe with a small concise menu strong caffeine in the neighborhood! Only thing missing is seating/studying area in this cafe and it would've been 5 stars...

I have been searching for a cafe close to my house and surprisingly found Four Barrel off of San Bruno Ave! So when I really want a good strong cup of latte or mocha I can go here. Again if it has a studying/seating area, I'd be here more often.

Menu is small, so you will not have a hard and long time trying to figure out what you want. Other than the drinks, they also have the toast with 2 spreads on top. The toast looks really good. But I cannot get myself pay $4 for one somewhat thick slice of toast with 2 spreads on it with a drink that costs around $4-$5. The drink and the toast is like the price of a meal/sandwich, but it is not a meal! So I'll just get drinks here =)
author: Shirley M.

description:
Literally a hole in the wall, underneath a billboard, 
black exterior, minimalistic design interior, 
the best part, the barista, 
female barista with the beanie in the morning, mad props, 
multitaskin', barista and cashier, 
nice, friendly, and makes a mean latte, 
dedicated service, call that one-on-one, 
unrushed cup of coffee, with foam steamed to perfection,
first time visitn' some guy was talkin' about trippin' LSD, best believe hipster certified
author: Roy C.

description:
Yes!!! So happy Four Barrel has come to our hood, minus the hipsters and techies. Great coffee and friendly faces. Trevor was a pleasure, very helpful and friendly. 

And the coffee was fantastic.
author: Nathan U.

description: Amazing find in Portola! Best coffee in the city and the regeneration of their road is beautiful
author: James W.

description:
I love the concept and idea of this place incorporating solar panels and eco-friendly products. Nothing can be more San Franciscan than that.

Lovely place, very hidden off, you wouldn't know it's there unless you actually know its there. Otherwise you could probably walk past it every day. 
I really hope they can have some kind of visible signage for this location. 

Coffee is great, simple and staff is friendly and inviting. 
Seating is available, but minimal as in just a few stools laying around. Not that many would mind since it appears to be a grab and go place. 

Wallet friendly? For those who grab coffee once or more daily, you do pay $4 for a small to medium sized latte, where you could get a good quality large latte for less somewhere else.
author: Veronica L.

description:
I've been going to the Four Barrel in the Mission since it opened. By far my favorite experience all around. I love their coffee, the employees are always courteous, and the space is great. So you can imagine how excited I was to learn that they opened closer to my house. 

The new space is fantastic. Kinda hidden, set back from the main street, which I like. It's got a really great vibe, and is already a beacon in a neighborhood that's needed a facelift for some time.

Happy to call this my local coffee stop.
author: Bjorn P.

description:
Hey, finally a decent coffee place in the Portola! It's basically a kisok - little to no seating, but the outside pocket park is an awesome place to enjoy your coffee. I appreciate the bare bones coffee selection...coffee, iced coffee, latte, etc. Nothing too fancy sounding. I am excited to see how this place develops.

The barista gave me a free coconut cookie! Yay!
author: Belle Y.

description: Best coffee in the city if not... In the world!!! great customer service and friendly environment! Love it!!!
author: Ericka E.

description:
We have lived in the Portola for 15+ years and I could have never imagined we would have a fancy coffee place. My hubby and I checked it out and am happy to say it was a good experience. Cute space, even if sparse, nice barista, and good coffee and pastries. 

My latte was yummy and hubby had a basic coffee. The pastries were delicious!! We had one sweet and one savory. 

My main complaint would be that they need some small tables or one big, long communal one. Not having a place to set our pastries was a bummer. I meet with clients at coffee shops all the time, and would love to bring them here, but need a table and would probably like the option to sit inside. It does feel like they are not "done" with the inside with the lack of seats/tables. 

I wish them all the luck and hope to see tables soon, so I can come by with clients and show off my neighborhood!
author: Keri V.

description:
Four Barrel in Portola!? Wahoo!  

  My husband and I just bought a house in this up and coming neighborhood and were thrilled to hear that Four Barrel established a shop here too!  We went on Saturday to stroll the streets and check it out.

  This locations is quaint and charming.  The drinks are A+ just like the Mission location.  The staff was super friendly and seemed genuinely excited that we were there.  

  I am so thrilled that we have a "home base" coffee shop near our house.  Keep up the good work!
author: Krissy P.

description: You MUST try Four Barrel ! It's hidden behind Subway in a alley way. Four Barrel have friendly staff.  The Best Coffee in Portola District !
author: Katherine L.

description: Cool little hidden spot out here. Same great coffee as the big location. The only negative is that it gets really cold in there since there are large, open garage style doors.
author: Captain B.

description:
Living half-way between Ritual Roasters (at Flora Grubb) and Four Barrel on San Bruno Ave., I'm now blessed with a choice!  I am happy to say that the great folks and coffee at Four Barrel have essentially made that choice for me.

Their coffee is consistently delicious, regardless of the beans that they're using.  The know just how to roast them to bring out the most flavor in every cup.
author: Chris W.

description: Coffee is excellent. Dead end street with a nice patio and garden next door. The toast and toppings are delish. Pastries yummy. Great place to relax in the Portola/Bayview if you like good coffee. The staff is excellent, love em all, thanks to all the special baristas!
author: Brendan C.

description: The best coffee in the neighbourhood. Quite an unexpected surprise!
author: Rudy T.

description: We waited soooo long to have a good espresso and cup of coffee that is walkable from our place.  The plan is nice and simple. It will be a bit of a downer for when it is raining hard given the interior is sparse and small, but anything short of rain, the place will be great. The pastries are by neighbor... that ham tart might be the best breakfast pastry in the city for my tastes.
author: Audrey N.

description: So excited I have a Four Barrel location by my house! It is a lot easier to find parking in this neighborhood and the wait is nowhere near as long as the other location in the mission. I tend to come here in the mornings before I go to work. As always, the coffee is great. The location is very small and I would not recommend it for working on your laptop or anything like that, but It is a great addition to the neighborhood.
author: Breniel L.

description: The staff are sweet and helpful. The coffee is delicious. This is an AMAZING addition to our up-and-coming neighborhood!
author: Chase L.

description:
Really deserves 4 stars, but the value-add of a great coffee spot in this part of town must get rewarded.

Excellent coffee, well-prepared, can't go wrong.  Not even too pricey for good coffee.

Location is industrial/bleak, certainly not a place where you'll spend 2 hours working on your laptop - but I think that's probably a plus.  

Tip on finding this place: it's between the Subway and the freeway.  :)
author: Jeremy T.

description:
Delicious coffee and pastries. I ordered the mocha and pistachio/blackberry croissant. The mocha was better than average but not the best. However I was very impressed by the croissant!! So unique tasting and still fresh even though I didn't eat it until the afternoon. Apparently they get all of their pastries from Neighbor, which I will now have to try! 

I took off one star because it lacks any table area for reading or studying, so it is more of a grab and go place. They only have a bench and some stools.
author: Heidi Q.

description: Ok coffee, poor service. If you're going to charge $5 for a cup of mocha, you should probably say thank you at the end of the transaction and a little smile wouldn't hurt.
author: C B.

description: I had no idea Four Barrel had another location and this one has toast! My latte and toast were amazing, as expected, and it was fun to hang out in the park outside.
author: Amin S.

description:
At long last, not only do we have a cafe within walking distance for Portolans, but it's Four Barrel!! I am so grateful to Jeremy and his wonderful crew for making this happen. Superior coffee and yummy hot chocolate, sweet and savory pastries, shared with enthusiasm and expertise. 

Now if CalTrans would please get on board and permit us to clean up that disgusting alley between the buildings and the walled freeway, we'll really be in business with the pocket park.
author: Steep R.

description: it says their hours are 7-4 everyday. Walked in around 1:30pm. There's one barista present talking to two people, like they are so into their conversation we were ignored for about five minutes. Mind you, we were patient enough to wait that long for her to acknowledge us. But whatever. The good thing about this city is there's about a hundred other places I can get good coffee so I'm taking my money where my business is wanted.
author: Niko B.

description: They deserve zero stars. I ran out of my preferred coffee that I make at home everyday and so went for four barrel that morning (Thursday 07/14/16) - I arrived around 7:45 to a deserted parking lot when it is usually full. I assumed it was a fluke and as I walked toward Four Barrel it was closed. I thought, hm do they open at 8AM? (Odd since I have been there before 8AM) NOPE. I checked Google and sure enough their hours are listed as 7AM - 4PM. I took a screen cap of the google business listing, the business front closed, and a picture of my watch and sent them a tweet with said pictures asking what was up. My friend chimed in that was NO BUENO on their part. I inquired if the management was above covering for their staff? I received a tweet back several hours later (I assume after management dragged themselves out of bed), and they responded with a nasty sarcastic response inferring it was not the end of the world. Clearly, their ethos is the opposite of "the customer is always right". Yeah I'll take Fat Beli deli coffee any day over their overpriced coffee, and long waits, and HORRENDOUS attitude. I advised them they can go eff themselves. My apologies to your sensitive feelings Four Barrel Coffee management, apparently you do not care about peak hours where revenue is made for a coffee company. once again, go eff yourself.
author: Cassandra R.

description: Manages to both be more pretentious and have worse coffee than the Valencia location. Staff is too cool to make a decent cup of coffee or be pleasant and there were several flies buzzing around the awkwardly arranged interior. The only cool thing was the wooden ceiling but you can just walk in and take a look for free. Two stars for that!
author: Ayo R.

description: Their lattes are amazing. It is clean and has a good vibe with some parking. The minus star is for value and the 4 dollar toast. But I bet the 4 dollar toast is still good. The lattes sure are.
author: Patrick S.

description: Kind of sad to see a SOMA style cafe out here but decided to give it a try. Coffee was good. Normal in SF, but the staff seemed pretty cold, didn't talk much. Maybe because I didn't look like a hipster or someone who is in love with their coffee. The design of the place is pretty dark. All in all I will continue to drive out to trouble coffee, even though they don't have ample space or seating their coffee is on point and staff always greets me warm and well plus they dont have as much of a hipster vibe, it feels more original to SF.
author: Yosof R.

description: Ok....my review was filtered. Just goes to show how off yelp is.
author: Mike H.

description: Love the coffee and the hidden location away from the long lines in the Mission. Good place to drop in and grab a quick to-go cup but better seating and tables in addition to the stools would be a great addition to help create more of a hangout.
author: Alexander H.

description: I love the design of this place, I love that it's located close to my hood. The barista was really sweet with me and my dad when we stopped in, she explained the origins of the coffee and the pricing factors that make it a bit on the expensive side (basically this benefits coffee growers) The coffee was very good.
author: ellen c.

description:
I'm pretty hooked to Four Barrel's coffee. I crave it!

Refreshing, fruity, flavorful and strong coffee.

Really friendly, amiable staff here.

The ambiance is really cool and laid back... like you're going to visit your friends at their swanky, cozy industrial pad but they're also baristas and make you delicious coffee and have delicious croissants and pastries. Whaat? Nice. 

The pistachio croissant is amazing...always fresh and flakey I have no idea what the top part of the pistachio croissant is but it's like a chewy mouthwatering cookie blanketed with roasted pistachios on top. 

Their toast is pretty ridiculous (good) too.
author: Jesse K.

description: This place is absolutely fantastic! From the fresh, warm latte to the homemade cookies, you'll experience coffee in a whole new light! Quality is exuded throughout. The ambiance delivered such a unique experience by displaying an 'industrial like' themed presence. I normally like to sit at the bar in the back where I can watch them roast the coffee while I enjoy my fresh cup! This place gets very busy and it's not cheap, but it's what you should expect for great quality!
author: Kaycee L.

description: Well I waited years to get amazing coffee in my hood and this little shop fit the bill but unfortunitly has fallin short on seating design as you scrabble around to put little stools together to make a table. I'd go one big community table and I might go back :(
author: Jeffrey W.

description: This cafe feels like it is for a very specific audience. Very dark and little seating but nice interior and decoration. My only problem was that their hot chocolate wasn't really sweet and that there weren't really any places to sit and enjoy my drinks. Aside from that, good service and atmosphere.
author: Carmela Y.

description: I love this place. The coffee is always good and the staff is very friendly. I buy coffee there every few weeks to brew at home. I can't say enough good things about this location and brand.
author: Jason U.

description: Yelped for some good coffee near my job and came accross this place. So disappointed by the four stars it got. My pour over was more like watered down blond coffee.
author: Angie I.

description: I like the coffee at the Valencia location so I expected the same here. Sadly, my coffee tasted mostly like steamed milk that was steamed too much. There was also probably an espresso in there somewhere but very faint :( Doesn't deserve the same name as the Valencia four barrel yet.
author: Alex K.

description:
unfortunately, very disappointed that this place is not clean

WANTED TO TREAT MYSELF WITH EXPENSIVE COFFEE
Coffee is pricey, but I don't mind paying $3 for a cup of good coffee even if it is expensive... I don't even mind the fact that the seating is just couple of uncomfortable stools, no tables, I think it kind of adds to the corky style of the place.

WALKED OUT BECAUSE 
So I was really looking forward to treat myself today, but had to walk out of this coffee shop never to return because
1) I saw a dog roaming in the coffee shop, sniffing all around the tiny food carts that hold bread, sugar, cream, cups, etc. It was of course a happy dog so it was wagging its tail full of dog hair and dirt all aronud the food too :)
2) when I asked about it, the barrista said that they always let the pets to come into the shop and obviously they don't do anything to prevent the pets from getting on the food that is around the shop!

WHAT I THINK AND KNOW ABOUT PETS AND FOOD IN USA
I think either you should not allow pets into a coffee shop, and have designated outdoor area for pets.
Or if the pets can come into the shop, then the food has to be properly placed out of reach of the pet.
People like my family can be allergic to dog hair. Also it is unsanitary and illegal to have pets around food according to FDA policies. This is just food basics.
I mean this is wrong on so many levels.

I DON"T TRUST THEIR FOOD HANDLING PROCEDURES
So I will never buy coffee or a croissant or anything here, because I question whether the people here even wash their hands with this attitude about the cleanliness of the food!

GOT A NICE CUP OF COFFEE SOMEWHERE ELSE
I was happy to confidently walk across the street to the Sandwich shop and get my old cup of coffee and enjoy it because I knew at least at the Fat Belly Dely shop, they practice safe food handling procedures.
author: Maria S.

description: Cute hipster coffee shop in this area of town.  I love the decor of the ceiling.  Would have been better if there were more seating for coffee lovers to sit around and enjoy.  The coffee is good but does not live up to the hype that I've been hearing.
author: Shirley T.

description: Cute place. Affogato was tasty, but the quality of ice cream was noticeable by the ice chunks in it. But overall I'd visit again for some cold brew ice coffee.
author: Sheena L.

description: So happy to have this near our hood! Loved the cozy storefront, service by nice Japanese dude, and mini play zone on the hill for the kiddos. Oh yeah and of course the coffee & the pastries were killer. Would be even better with some small tables to go with the stools.
author: Jennifer D.

description: I'm not normally a coffee drinker but after finding out that a famous Four Barrel opened up in my hood, I checked it out.  Street parking can be a little tough on San Bruno Avenue and surrounding blocks and it's mostly metered.  But try parking on Burrows where Four Barrel is.  You may be able to park perpendicularly in front of the shop?  Not sure if that's allowed, but it might be cool if it's for a quick stop.  I tried the decaf almond milk latte.  Like I said before I'm not normally a coffee drinker, but it was smooth and didn't cause the runs and no jitters.  (Decaf still has some caffeine in it).  I'm a big fan of businesses adapting old industrial buildings for new uses which it looks like what Four Barrel did here.  They kept the interior pretty minimal to keep the industrial feel with a lot of green building features.  Every little bit helps.  Great addition to the hood.
author: Law C.

description:
A much needed and welcome addition to the Portola District!  

Simple and no fuss place to meet up with friends for a caffeine fix.  The folks who work here are friendly, down-to-earth, and know how to craft the perfect drink.  I was pleasantly surprised to see that they offer almond milk.

The pastries are done the right way - nice and flaky.  I've tried the pistachio, chocolate, and ham croissants (so far).  The pistachio croissant in particular is unique, so very tasty, and the perfect accompaniment to a cup of coffee in this minimalist space.  

Seating is limited to a few stools, which seemed bare to me at first, but now I get that it allows people to casually grab a few stools and chat with one another, all the while basking outside in one of the sunniest parts of the city.  Lovely! 

Extra points to the owner for having the creativity and vision to make this the most eco-friendly coffee shop around (perhaps in the universe?).  There are exciting plans to develop the adjacent area into a community space for neighbors to enjoy and share with visitors of the Portola District.  I'll be sure to share this gem with friends and family!  Awesome job.
author: Kate T.

description: This place is a neighborhood gem. The coffee is excellent, the staff is always super-friendly, and the shop itself is a lovely oasis tucked off San Bruno Avenue.
author: Erika C.

description: I work right next to this shop and I walked in and love the vibe it's very open spatially and the design of the place is so sick reminds me of some cool spots I've been on Venice Blvd. Anyway I went in and it rocked! The people holding the place down were so cool and what lit me up was when I went to add some milk to my coffee, I saw they had almond milk. I am your FAN man. Getting a cup every time I work.
author: Hooman T.

description: Portola neighborhood could really use a good coffee shop, and we do welcome their business.  However, I wish they would make their place more cozy like a real coffee shop where we can order our drinks sit comfortably to read a book or surf the web. They only have stools outside and gets cold after awhile.  So it's meant a drink&go type of places.  Hopefully next time they can furnish the place for a more welcoming place for a cup of coffee!
author: Sid C.

description:
DEElicious coffee.  Had a great pistachio croissant too.

You can park in the Bank of the West lot around the corner on San Bruno.  

Hey, any chance they could use the alley next to the freeway?  Tear down the pointless wire fence gate, get rid of the crap in there, put a couple of tables in.
author: Barry K.

description:
Been going to their other location. this one is closer to my place, easier to find parking.

this place does not have analog music from mc30, but coffee is just as good.
author: Kee P.

description: The coffee is good, but not fantastic. The prices were reasonable and the atmosphere is pretty nice. The one problem is a serious lack of seating and tables. If you want to do some work this is not a great place to do it. I came with the intention of spending a couple hours here. Instead I decided to enjoy a cup of coffee and then find a more comfortable place to finish my work. Worth a visit though!
author: Scott H.

description: I love the new Four Barrel in the Portola. The coffee at $2.50 a cup is affordable and the staff is friendly. The ceiling is worth a look as it is quite unusual. The outdoor seating is adjacent to a new park that will soon have public artwork and seating.  UPDATE: Their hours have been extended from 7:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m.
author: Ruth W.

description: We just moved into Portola District and we were given the best move-in gift ever:  Four Barrel Coffee!!  We are very excited to have this new cool place were we can hang out with friends and relax under the sun - there's a big open space right outside the store and a number chairs are also available in case you get tired or need somewhere to put your stuff on.  The folks working there are super friendly and laid-back.  I hope they could put up their sign soon so more people would get the news that Four Barrel Coffee moved in this neighborhood!
author: Bonnie W.
